sections.section_name:
IE 200: SUMMER
PRACTICE I
INTERNSHIP REPORT
Name & Surname: Selin Aliakar
Student ID: 042203103
sections.content:
IE 200: SUMMER
PRACTICE I
INTERNSHIP REPORT
Name & Surname: Selin Aliakar
Student ID: 042203103

Executive Summary
During my internship at Delta Genset, I had the opportunity to deeply examine the
generator production process and observe its various stages. My time in the production department
provided me with the chance to apply the industrial engineering knowledge in practice and gain a
better understanding of production processes.
At the beginning of my internship, after receiving a work order, I closely examined the
design and planning stages, which are fundamental to the production process. In this phase, I
observed the work done on the design criteria and engineering calculations for the generators. I
also participated in identifying missing materials, as well as in the procurement and storage
processes. I observed how material flow and inventory control were managed. On the production
line, I studied the assembly and testing phases of the generators in detail. During the assembly
phase, I observed the processes of combining the main components of the generators, installing
the engine, connecting the electrical parts, and placing other components. In the testing processes
conducted after assembly, I noted that the performance of the generators was evaluated under
various operating conditions and that compliance with established quality standards was checked.
The quality control process aims to ensure that each product meets the standards, thereby
maintaining a high level of customer satisfaction. I had the opportunity to examine the problems
encountered in the production process and the methods used to solve them. In the troubleshooting
process, production line issues were quickly identified, and necessary corrective actions were
taken. Additionally, I assessed the impact of continuous improvement efforts on enhancing the
efficiency of production processes.
My experience at Delta Genset allowed me to comprehensively learn every phase of the
generator production process. At the outset of my internship, I expected to gain practical insights
into the application of my theoretical knowledge in industrial engineering. I gained a wide range
of knowledge, from design and planning stages to material procurement, assembly, testing, and
quality control processes. This experience allowed me to develop specific problem-solving
techniques vital in manufacturing settings. Understanding material flow and inventory
management has equipped me to address similar challenges in the future.

Overview of Sector and Company
Delta Genset Makine A.Ş is an anonymous ownership company which is located in
Yakuplu Neighborhood, Göçmen Street No:1/160, Beylikdüzü, Istanbul, Turkey.
It began its production journey in 1991 in the field of Power Electronics. Since its establishment,
the company has aimed to become a significant player in the global generator manufacturing
market, growing in parallel with developments in the industry and establishing an international
customer base. This company has over 200 qualified personnel.
The organizational structure at Delta Genset fosters collaboration and streamlined
communication across various departments. The General Manager oversees all operations,
ensuring alignment with the company’s strategic objectives.

The General Manager serves as the central figure, overseeing all operations and ensuring
alignment with the company’s strategic objectives. Directly reporting to the General Manager are
the Production Manager, Project Manager, Quality Control Manager, Marketing and Sales
Manager, HR Manager, Finance Manager, and Logistics Manager, each responsible for their

respective domains. The Production Manager coordinates closely with the Production Planning
Chief and the engineering team, which includes the Production Engineer and technicians, to ensure
efficient manufacturing processes. This team is responsible for planning production schedules,
managing resources, and ensuring quality standards are met during assembly and testing phases.
The Project Manager oversees project execution, collaborating with the Design Engineer, Process
Engineer, and R&D Engineer to develop innovative products and optimize production techniques.
This synergy between project management and engineering is essential for continuous
improvement and product development. In terms of quality assurance, the Quality Control
Manager leads a dedicated team that includes specialists and technicians, ensuring that all products
meet established standards before they reach the market. This department interacts closely with
production to promptly address any quality issues. The Marketing and Sales Manager works to
drive revenue through market analysis and customer engagement, supported by the Marketing
Specialist and Sales Representative who implement marketing strategies and manage client
relationships. Human resources, led by the HR Manager, plays a crucial role in recruiting, training,
and maintaining employee satisfaction, which is essential for operational success. The HR
department collaborates with all units to address personnel needs and foster a positive work
environment. The Finance Manager ensures the company’s financial health through budgeting,
reporting, and financial analysis, while the Logistics Manager coordinates supply chain activities,
managing inventory, shipping, and purchasing to ensure smooth operations.
The interconnected roles within Delta Genset contribute to an efficient production process.
The Production Manager, alongside the Project Manager, ensures that product development aligns
with manufacturing capabilities, facilitating a smooth transition from design to assembly and
testing. Quality control processes are integrated throughout, ensuring compliance with standards
at each production stage. This holistic approach fosters continuous improvement and drives the
company toward its strategic goals.
Overall, the interconnected roles within the organizational structure of Delta Genset enable
effective communication, collaboration, and operational efficiency, driving the company toward
its strategic goals.
The production process is not merely a sequence of stages; each stage is dependent on the
preceding ones and has its own integrity. The first stage, the receipt of the work order, forms the
foundation of the production process. At this stage, a production plan is developed based on

customer needs and requests. Work orders are critical for determining production capacity and
allocating labor. During this stage, the production planning team utilizes historical data and market
analyses to make demand forecasts, shaping the production process accordingly. Material
management plays a vital role in the success of the production process. Monitoring for missing
materials and placing necessary orders enhance the effectiveness of the supply chain. Accelerating
the procurement process shortens production time and consequently increases customer
satisfaction. It is crucial to manage the material procurement process with a focus on quality, not
just price. High-quality materials directly impact the quality of the final product. Distributing the
production plan to different units clarifies role distribution within the organization and ensures that
each unit fulfills its responsibilities. Electrical assembly, mechanical assembly, and other units
create synergy by working within their areas of expertise. However, effective communication and
coordination are essential throughout this phase. Efficient communication among units helps
prevent potential errors and ensures the uninterrupted continuation of the production process. The
production of semi-finished products is one of the most critical points in the process. This stage
forms the first step in quality control procedures. At every stage, craftsmanship errors or material
defects are checked. Any disruption at any stage of the production process can lead to significant
issues in the final product. Therefore, all units must work closely together throughout the process.
The testing phase guarantees the quality of the product. Testing the produced generators assesses
both their reliability and performance. During this stage, compliance with international standards
is verified. The quality control department intervenes at every stage of the process to ensure that
products are manufactured to high standards, which is a critical element for the organization’s
reputation. In conclusion, Delta Genset's production process can be viewed as a system where each
stage interacts with one another, contributing to the achievement of the organization’s overall
goals. The systems perspective also helps identify areas for improvement to make this process
more efficient. Continuously reviewing and enhancing processes is essential for maintaining the
organization's competitive advantage. Thus, a systematic approach plays a critical role in
strengthening Delta Genset’s market position.

sections.section_name:
Professional and Ethical Responsibilities
Engineering Activities
sections.content:
Professional and Ethical Responsibilities
Engineering Activities
Design and Planning ● Development of design criteria and
engineering calculations for generators.
● Creation of production schedules based on
customer needs and historical data.
● Forecasting demand using market
analysis.
Material Management ● Identification of material requirements
and management of inventory.
● Communication with suppliers for
material procurement.
● Monitoring and managing material flow to
ensure timely availability.
Production Planning ● Allocation of labor hours and workforce
distribution.
● Integration of data into comprehensive
production plans.
● Coordination of production schedules
across different units.
Assembly Processes ● Supervision of the production of semi-
finished products.
Quality Control ● Implementation of quality assurance
checks throughout the production process.
● Performance testing of generators under
various operating conditions.
● Compliance verification with international
quality standards.

Testing and Validation ● Conducting load tests, voltage tests, and
current tests on assembled generators.
Recording and analyzing test results to
ensure performance reliability.
● Data entry and management for quality
assurance documentation.
Troubleshooting and Problem Solving ● Identifying and addressing production line
issues.
Continuous Improvement Initiatives ● Analyzing production data to identify
areas for efficiency enhancements.
Logistics Coordination ● Collaborating with logistics teams to plan
shipping and delivery of finished
products.
Team Collaboration and Communication ● Working closely with various units
(mechanical, electrical, cutting, welding,
etc.) to ensure cohesive operation.
● Engaging in team meetings to present
findings and suggest improvements.

sections.section_name:
Delta Genset, as a manufacturer of generators, embraces various professional and ethical
responsibilities related to engineering activities.
sections.content:
Delta Genset, as a manufacturer of generators, embraces various professional and ethical
responsibilities related to engineering activities. The company continuously strives to meet high-
quality production standards and customer satisfaction in its engineering operations. In this
context, the ethical responsibilities of engineers and employees are supported by a written code of
conduct. This code emphasizes fundamental values such as honesty, fairness, transparency, and
reliability. Professionals working in engineering bear responsibilities regarding environmental
sustainability, safety, and quality. Engineers at Delta Genset must adhere to principles such as
using environmentally friendly materials in product design and production processes, enhancing
energy efficiency, and minimizing waste. Additionally, it is essential that production processes
comply with health and safety standards to protect the well-being and safety of employees. The
company has demonstrated its commitment to environmental responsibility by obtaining the ISO

14001 certification, showcasing its efforts to achieve cost savings related to environmental impact.
Employees also have ethical responsibilities, such as ensuring transparent communication in
projects, contributing to teamwork, and showing respect for colleagues. This not only fosters a
positive work environment but also enhances the overall performance of the company. In
conclusion, the employees and engineers at Delta Genset understand the importance of ethical and
professional responsibilities, reflecting these obligations in their work lives, thereby enhancing the
company's reputation and reliability. This understanding supports success at both individual and
organizational levels.

Activity Analysis
During my internship at Delta Genset, I was involved in a comprehensive project focused
on the production of 110 kVa diesel generators. This activity encompassed the entire production
cycle, from initial planning and material procurement to assembly, testing, and logistics
coordination. My role involved collaborating with various teams to ensure that each phase of the
project was executed efficiently. I assisted in developing production schedules, identifying
material needs, and communicating with suppliers to secure necessary components. Additionally,
I participated in the assembly process, where I worked closely with mechanical and electrical units
to ensure quality standards were met. The project required meticulous planning and coordination
among multiple departments, including cutting, bending, welding, and testing. By engaging in this
multifaceted process, I gained valuable insights into production management, teamwork, and the
technical aspects of generator assembly, all of which are crucial in the manufacturing industry.
I engaged in key industrial engineering activities like production planning, material
management, quality control, effectivity analysis, communication, and coordination. I observed
their relationship to my academic studies. I had the opportunity to apply essential planning skills,
such as determining workforce and material requirements. I observed material flow by putting into
practice theoretical knowledge related to supply chain management and inventory control. My
observations of the effectiveness of quality assurance processes aligned with what I learned about
quality management systems. In order to increase the efficiency of the production process, I
observed quality control processes and better understood the role of these processes in industrial
engineering. My experiences in team communication and project management skills were

I engaged in key industrial engineering activities like production planning, material
management, quality control, effectivity analysis, communication, and coordination. I observed
their relationship to my academic studies. I had the opportunity to apply essential planning skills,
such as determining workforce and material requirements. I observed material flow by putting into
practice theoretical knowledge related to supply chain management and inventory control. My
observations of the effectiveness of quality assurance processes aligned with what I learned about
quality management systems. In order to increase the efficiency of the production process, I
observed quality control processes and better understood the role of these processes in industrial
engineering. My experiences in team communication and project management skills were

significantly enhanced during the internship. These activities strengthened the connections
between my major studies in industrial engineering and provided me with deeper theoretical
knowledge alongside practical skills development.
In the initial stage of the activity, after receiving the work order, design engineers drew a
generator model. This model is below:
Then, the dimensions of the generator were determined as follows: length 2900 mm, width
1100 mm, and height 1800 mm. The aim of determining the dimensions is if any part of the
generator needs to be replaced, these drawings are used to provide the correct size part. In addition,
the dimensions in the drawing can be checked to see if the generator is suitable for the dimensions
of the area where it will be placed.
After that, we collaborated with the production planning manager and process engineers to
create monthly and weekly plans. We conducted a thorough analysis to determine the required
workforce and material needs. While setting our production targets, we considered historical
production data and market demands. At this stage, I recorded the data in Excel and assisted the
relevant units while creating the supply lists. For example, below is the bearing supply list I
created:

This bearing procurement list has been created for the purpose of ordering various materials
and equipment to be used in the generator production process. The list covers a wide range of
products, from gloves and pipe wrenches to tapes and hoses. A total of 16 different products are
included, and quantities have been specified for each item. Bearings play a critical role in the
generator production process by ensuring that moving parts operate smoothly and efficiently. For
example, during the rotational movement of the generator's rotor, bearings minimize friction,
enhance energy efficiency, and prevent wear. Therefore, selecting the correct type and quality of
bearings is crucial for the generator's longevity and trouble-free operation. With this procurement
list, we aim to ensure the complete acquisition of the necessary bearings and other related
components required for the generator production process.

This is the electrical material list I prepared:
This Excel sheet has been prepared for the procurement of electrical and mechanical
connection materials to be used in the generator production process. The materials listed have been
identified to ensure the correct and safe assembly of various components of the generator.
Electrical materials play a critical role in both the creation of the generator's electrical circuits and
the assembly of its mechanical parts.
We allocated a total of 1200 hours of labor to produce four generators, averaging 300 hours
of labor per generator. The hours per generator were 287.5, a deviation of -12.5 hours. This
reduction in time demonstrates improvements in workflow and the potential for scaling production
in future projects. Our material list included the engine, chassis, electrical components, and other
necessary parts, totaling approximately 4000 kg of materials. There was a waste of 200 kg of
materials and the targeted 100% material efficiency was not as expected.
After that, we identified material shortages and communicated with suppliers. The
identified missing materials were:
● Engine Coolant - 20 liters
● Oil - 30 liters
● Battery - 4 units
● Control Board - 4 units
● Cables and Connectors - 100 meters
● Fuses - 20 units

The procurement time for these materials varied based on their type. For instance, the
procurement time for engine coolant and oil was estimated at 1-3 days, while batteries and control
boards required 3-5 days. Effectively managing procurement timelines was crucial for ensuring
our production schedule progressed without interruptions. Timely identification of material
shortages and prompt ordering enhanced the efficiency of our production process. Once we
completed the material needs and labor planning, we integrated this data into the production plan.
The production plan included the production schedule for the generators, the necessary workforce
distribution, and material flow. At this stage, we precisely determined when and in what quantities
materials would be required.
After finalizing the production plan, we distributed it to the relevant units involved in the
production process:
● Electrical Unit: Planning the assembly and testing processes of electrical components. I
contributed to the preparation of the electrical connection diagram and checked the
required parts during assembly.
● Mechanical Unit: Assembly of the chassis and engine and checking mechanical
components. I assisted in the assembly of mechanical parts and supported quality control
processes.
● Cutting Unit: Cutting processes for metals and other materials. I helped plan cutting
processes and prepared checklists to ensure the accuracy and timeliness of material cutting.
● Bending Unit: Planning the bending operations of metal parts. I monitored the regular
maintenance of the machines used in this process.
● Welding Unit: Performing welding operations during assembly. I provided safety
information regarding welding equipment to fellow interns and assisted in quality control
checks.
● Cabin Unit: Production and assembly of the generator cabin. I contributed to the cabin
design and assembly.
● Testing Unit: Conducting performance tests on the produced generators. I observed the
testing processes and monitored the performance of the generators.
Each unit followed the production plan distributed to them, determining when and how to
use the materials throughout the process. This communication and coordination facilitated a

smooth progression of the production process. I was involved in the production process as an
industrial engineering intern, and I also helped the technicians and examined every stage of the
process.
Below is the image of the electrical panel where the components that control the operation
of the generators are assembled:
I learned that the electrical panel in this image plays a critical role in generators and is
typically used for control, monitoring, and safety purposes. The control system in this panel is used
to start or stop the generator in case of an emergency and to monitor various parameters. Various
relays and fuses are included in this panel to protect the generator against overload, low voltage,
excessive temperature, or other fault conditions. These protective components ensure the safe
operation of the generator. The terminal blocks and power supply units in the panel are used to
safely distribute the electricity generated by the generator to various locations. Electrical panels
ensure that this electricity is transmitted at the correct voltage and amperage levels.

I had the opportunity to observe the production of the engine block, which is considered
the heart of a generator. This process includes various steps such as casting, machining, quality
control, and assembly. In the photo below, the engine is displayed:
First, all the technical details of the engine block were determined. Then, molds were
prepared using durable and high-temperature resistant materials and molten metal was poured into
these molds. The cooled engine block was brought to the desired shape during the processing phase
and its surfaces were smoothed. Finally, other parts were assembled into the engine block and
completed. During the internship, I took part in every stage of engine block production and
observed how delicate and careful this process is. I also learned the general features of the engine
and the effects of these features. An Excel sheet containing the general features of the engine is
below:

While preparing this sheet, I also learned how features affect the engine. For example, I
learned that the total volume of the cylinders is directly related to the engine's power, that a high
compression ratio means higher efficiency, that standby power is the reserve power used for
emergency situations, and that prime power is the power used for continuously operating
applications. At 100% load, the generator consumes 21.25 liters of fuel per hour, which is the
maximum fuel consumption. When the load drops to 75%, the fuel consumption decreases to 16.01
liters/hour, which represents a reduction of approximately 24.65%. When the load drops to 50%,
the fuel consumption decreases further to 10.58 liters/hour, which is a reduction of 33.94%. In
doing this analysis, we have made the following criticism: As the load decreases, the amount of
fuel used to produce a unit of power decreases. This means that the engine operates more
efficiently at low loads. However, at very low loads, the engine's efficiency may decrease again.
The production of the alternator, which converts mechanical energy into electrical energy,
began. I closely observed the process and assisted the technicians. After manufacturing some parts
of the stator and rotor, they were machined to the required dimensions and their surfaces were
finished. The stator laminations were cut using laser or plasma cutting units. An insulation process
was applied to prevent the windings from short-circuiting. Once all the parts were assembled, the

electrical unit made the connections and installed auxiliary electrical equipment like the voltage
regulator. After undergoing necessary electrical and mechanical tests, the alternator was sent for
painting.

The visual of the laser cutting machine used at this stage is below.

I then created an Excel file containing the specifications of the manufactured alternator:
My involvement in the production of key components, such as the engine block and
alternator, allowed me to appreciate the intricate details that contribute to a generator's
performance. I learned how engineering specifications directly influence fuel efficiency and
operational reliability. The collaborative efforts among different units emphasized the necessity of
clear communication and coordination in achieving a successful production outcome. Overall, this
experience not only reinforced my theoretical knowledge in industrial engineering but also
enhanced my practical skills in problem-solving and teamwork.
As the production process progressed, we successfully completed the production of semi-
finished products, a critical phase in the overall project. When we faced an unexpected delay from
our supplier for a specific type of connector used in the production of electrical panels, we
reviewed our production plan and developed an alternative solution. In this process, we conducted
a critical path analysis with our electrical unit and reorganized the production sequence. By
postponing the final stage where the connectors were used, we continued the assembly of other
components on the production line. In this way, we managed to complete different components
without completely stopping production. Once the connector supply was completed, we returned

the production line to its previous state as soon as possible and completed the delivery to the
customer on the promised date without any delay. This experience once again demonstrated the
importance of flexibility in production planning and allowed us to develop different scenarios for
potential risks.
I also actively participated in producing essential components, including the cabin, chassis,
panel, and various mechanical parts. By meticulously checking the suitability of the materials used,
I coordinated closely with my teammates to ensure that each component met our strict quality
standards and was produced on schedule. Once the semi-finished products were completed, we
seamlessly transitioned to the assembly of the generators. During this phase, I took the opportunity
to observe the testing processes, closely monitoring the calibration of the testing equipment to
ensure accuracy. I assisted in conducting a range of tests, including load tests, voltage assessments,
and current measurements; I recorded each result with precision and contributed to their thorough
analysis. After the testing was finalized, I ensured that all relevant information for each generator
was accurately entered into the system. My attention to detail extended to the invoicing process,
where I helped guarantee the correct preparation of invoices, ensuring all necessary information
was complete and accurate. These documents played a crucial role in the documentation of the
shipping process, which is vital for maintaining efficient operations. Furthermore, we established
the shipment dates for the generators and developed a comprehensive loading plan. Collaborating
with logistics teams, I contributed to arranging the necessary logistics for the shipment, which
highlighted the importance of effective communication across departments.

The experiences I gained during my internship underscored the significance of material
management, production planning, and teamwork. I am confident that these experiences will
provide invaluable insights and skills that I can apply to future projects, enhancing my ability to
contribute effectively in the field of industrial engineering.

Conclusion
During my internship at Delta Genset, I discovered how important it is to develop new
skills in today's fast-changing industrial world. As I worked through different stages of the
generator production process, I faced challenges that showed me where I needed to grow. One key
area where I gained new skills was in analyzing production data. I learned to use software tools to
look at metrics like how long tasks took and how well resources were used. This skill helped me
spot delays in the assembly line and suggest practical solutions, such as changing worker schedules
and improving material flow. By using this new skill, I recommended a change that reduced
downtime. I also realized the need for better communication and teamwork skills. Working with a
diverse team made it clear how important it is to express ideas and feedback clearly. I took part in
meetings where I had to share my findings and suggestions, which helped me improve my ability
to explain technical information in a simple way. This experience built my confidence and helped
the team achieve its goals. The fast pace of changes in technology and methods in manufacturing
highlights the importance of ongoing professional development. To remain competitive, workers
must keep updating their skills. My time at Delta Genset showed me that learning new tools and
processes can lead to significant improvements in production efficiency and product quality.
Delta Genset also operates in a competitive market and faces several challenges. The
company's ability to adapt to technological advancements and changing customer demands will be
crucial for its continued success. Additionally, navigating global supply chain disruptions and
ensuring efficient logistics operations are ongoing challenges.
Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things are two significant technologies with
the potential to revolutionize generator manufacturing and usage. AI can play a crucial role in
optimizing production processes, predictive maintenance, and quality control. For instance, AI
algorithms can analyze production data to predict machine failures in advance and adjust
production parameters to enhance product quality. Consequently, production efficiency can be
increased, costs can be reduced, and product durability can be ensured. IoT, on the other hand,
provides the capability to collect real-time data through sensors connected to generators. This data
can be utilized to understand generator performance, fuel consumption, operating conditions, and
potential issues. For example, when an anomaly is detected in a generator, the system can

automatically send an alert to the maintenance team and trigger the necessary intervention. This
minimizes unplanned downtime and increases energy efficiency.
In conclusion, AI and IoT technologies can become a significant transformation in
generator manufacturing and usage in 5-10 years in the generator industry. So, generators will
become more efficient, reliable, and sustainable.

Impacts
In today's world, engineering decisions must consider international standards and practices.
By adhering to global quality standards in the production of generators, Delta Genset positions
itself competitively in the international market and sells to a lot of countries around the world. This
commitment to quality contributes to the global supply chain, facilitating trade and cooperation.
During this internship time, I saw that the production process directly impacts economic factors,
including cost efficiency. By optimizing material flow and minimizing waste, the company tries
to reduce production costs. Engineering decisions at Delta Genset incorporate sustainability
considerations, reflecting a growing awareness of environmental impacts. The choice of materials
shows environmentally friendly options and energy-efficient designs. The societal impact of
engineering decisions is also important because the production of reliable and efficient generators
contributes to critical infrastructure, such as hospitals, schools, and businesses, ensuring that
communities have access to uninterrupted power supply. It increases the quality of life for
individuals and supports economic activities. In conclusion, the engineering decisions made during
my internship at Delta Genset reflect a comprehensive understanding of the multifaceted impacts
of industrial activities. By considering global, economic, environmental, and societal contexts, the
company not only enhances its operational efficiency but also contributes positively to broader
community and environmental goals. These insights will be invaluable as I continue my studies
and future career in industrial engineering.

Teamwork
Executive Management Team
● General Manager: Oversees all company operations, sets strategic goals, and ensures their
execution.
● Production Manager: Ensures the efficiency and effectiveness of production processes.
Responsible for production planning, resource management, and quality control.
● Project Manager: Manages new product development projects. Collaborates closely with
design, process development, and R&D departments.
● Quality Control Manager: Ensures products meet quality standards. Manages quality
control processes and resolves quality issues in production.
● Marketing and Sales Manager: Markets company products and achieves sales targets.
Conducts market research, develops sales strategies, and manages customer relationships.
● Human Resources Manager: Responsible for recruitment, training, and performance
management. Works to improve employee satisfaction.
● Finance Manager: Manages the company's financial situation. Creates budgets, prepares
financial reports, and conducts financial analyses.
● Logistics Manager: Responsible for supply chain management, inventory control, and
shipping.
Production Department
● Production Planning Chief: Creates production plans and allocates resources.
● Production Engineer: Optimizes production processes and develops new production
methods.
Project Management Department
● Design Engineer: Designs new products.
● Process Engineer: Analyzes production processes and suggests improvements.
● R&D Engineer: Researches new technologies and contributes to product development
efforts.

Quality Control Department
● Quality Control Specialists: Oversee product compliance with quality standards.
● Quality Control Technicians: Conduct product tests.
Marketing and Sales Department
● Marketing Specialist: Conducts market research and develops marketing strategies.
● Sales Representative: Sells products to customers and manages customer relationships.
Finance Department
● Accounting Team: Records financial transactions and prepares reports.
● Budget Analysts: Create budgets and analyze financial performance.
Logistics Department
● Logistics Specialists: Responsible for supply chain management and logistics operations.
Effective communication is the lifeblood of Delta Genset, underpinning the smooth
operation of its business and the attainment of its corporate objectives. The coordination between
different departments, the management of projects, and the resolution of problems are all heavily
reliant on efficient communication. Regular meetings are held throughout the company to facilitate
information sharing, problem-solving, and decision-making among teams. These meetings vary in
frequency, ranging from daily stand-ups and weekly team meetings to monthly departmental
gatherings. Additionally, managers often foster an open-door policy, encouraging employees to
approach them with questions or concerns at any time. This creates a more transparent and
approachable communication environment.
By implementing these communication strategies, Delta Genset ensures a seamless flow of
information within the organization, leading to enhanced collaboration, increased productivity,
and improved decision-making.

Self-Directed Learning
During my internship at Delta Genset, I actively focused on self-learning to enhance my
skills and knowledge. I realized how important continuous professional development is in today's
rapidly changing industrial environment.
By seeking out additional resources, I had the opportunity to deepen my understanding of
industrial engineering principles and their practical applications. One of my self-learning strategies
was to review industry-specific articles. These resources provided valuable insights into the latest
trends, technological advancements, and best practices in generator manufacturing. Additionally,
collaborating with my colleagues and seeking mentorship played a significant role in my
professional development. Discussions with experienced engineers and technicians allowed me to
gain valuable perspectives and benefit from their expertise. By actively seeking guidance and
feedback, I identified my areas for improvement and developed effective problem-solving
strategies. For instance, while working with electrical engineers, we conducted performance tests
on generators and quickly addressed the issues we encountered, thereby increasing efficiency in
the process. These collaborations not only enhanced my technical skills but also strengthened
communication and solidarity within the team. Thanks to the experiences of my colleagues, I was
able to produce more comprehensive solutions to the challenges I faced, which became one of the
most valuable aspects of my internship.
In conclusion, my commitment to self-learning played a critical role during my internship
at Delta Genset. Through my active efforts to acquire new knowledge and skills, I gained a better
understanding of industrial engineering principles and contributed more effectively to the
production process. This ongoing desire for learning will undoubtedly be a valuable asset in my
future career, enhancing my ability to adapt in dynamic environments.
